content: Thank you to everyone who reviewed and provided advice for improvement.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy to solve and fun.

Comment: This contribution for a clash of code is interesting with a double system of sorting with rank and alphabetically !

1. No brackets are required around "The rank of a letter..."
2. Don't put examples in the Input and Output sections.
3. Refer to Blabbage's comments below and the example in the guidelines on how to format and present your Inputs and Outputs (e.g. use Line 1, Next N lines): https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement#guidelines
4. Format n in the Constraints section.
5. Remove the extra dot in the third line in the Constraints section.
Thank you to everyone who provided me feedback. I have clarified the problem statement and explained more fully what Rank Sum means, and now moved this from WiP to Ready.
I think this is very nice not very hard but also challenging.
Very good good, i like it

I like the puzzle a lot. Very good for all game modes in my opinion, including reverse.

I think it was a bit unclear to me what I had to do. I didn't understand the assignment until after reading the tests.

The first line:
Compute the rank sum for n ordered sequences of letters.

made no sense to me as I never heard of "rank sum" before.

the next line:
(Rank is 1-indexed: 1st letter has rank 1, 2nd rank 2, etc.)

Did not help me, as it implies that rank is an established name for something I should know what is.

You could change to something like:
Compute the rank sum for n ordered sequences of letters

The ranks are the 1-based index for each letter in the input string.
EXAMPLE

INPUT
Line 1: A M B -> A has rank 1, M has rank 2 and B has rank 3
Line 2: M I B  -> M has rank 1, I has rank 2 and B has rank 3

OUTPUT
A  1     (1)
M 3     (2+1)
B  6     (3+3)

The letters should be ordered lowest rank-sum first, and second alphabetically

Test "Longer" and Validator 4 seemed incorrect and so I submitted some corrections. I also added ", etc" to the wording at the end of the Goal statement. Of course, feel free to change as you see fit.

I like the concept, it would be a fun clash. It leans a little towards the difficult side for 15 minutes IMO, but it's fairly easy to understand so almost all of the time can be spent implementing the solution.

Thanks for the contribution!
Thanks so much for the feedback. I'll take a look at the corrections - thank you!

Thank you for taking he time to look at this puzzle. I can see now that there is some 'implicit knowledge' needed which won't necessarily be held by everyone. I think more clarity would help - thank you!
Thank you for the feedback - it is encouraging!
Thank you for the input, it is nice to get a feel for how others rate the difficulty level.
Brilliant thank you - that will help me polish it up
